original_data.question: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of worsening shortness of breath for 6 hours. For the past 5 days, he has had intermittent stabbing pain in the middle of his chest that worsens with lying down or taking deep breaths. He has also had a runny nose and a dry cough for the past 2 weeks. He has hypercholesterolemia and hypertension. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 34 years. His current medications include atorvastatin, enalapril, and hydrochlorothiazide. He appears pale and sweaty. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 105/min, and respirations are 25/min. Blood pressure is 107/72 mm Hg during expiration and 86/65 mm Hg during inspiration. Examination shows jugular venous distention and pitting edema below the knees. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?

options.A: Dilation of the atria and ventricles
options.C: Accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space

model_response:
The patient's symptoms and physical findings are consistent with cardiac tamponade, which is caused by accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space. The most common cause of tamponade in this patient is constrictive pericarditis, which is characterized by fibrous thickening of the pericardium. The accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space causes elevation of the intrapericardial pressure, which results in decreased ventricular filling and reduced cardiac output. The most common cause of constrictive pericarditis is previous episodes of acute pericarditis, especially hemorrhagic, suppurative, and caseous pericarditis. The other choices are unlikely causes of tamponade in this patient.

Other causes of tamponade include rapid accumulation of blood (eg, from ruptured myocardial infarction, trauma) and neoplastic disease. The most common causes of tamponade in a postoperative patient are bleeding and serous fluid accumulation.

The pain associated with tamponade is often described as stabbing and is located substernally. Dyspnea and orthopnea are common symptoms. The physical findings include jugular venous distention and pitting edema. The chest radiograph may show cardiomegaly, pleural effusions, and pulmonary vascular congestion. Echocardiography is the diagnostic test of choice. It shows pericardial fluid and a characteristic "water bottle" appearance of the heart.

Treatment of tamponade consists of drainage of the pericardial fluid. This can be done by pericardiocentesis or surgical pericardiotomy.

###Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Hospital department responsible for the administration and provision of immediate medical or surgical care to the emergency patient.
Height greater than two standard deviations below the mean of the appropriate reference population for the age and sex of the individual.
The air that is inhaled and exhaled during respiration.
A unit measure of time equal to 3,600 seconds or 60 minutes. It is approximately 1/24 of a median day.
The time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis; ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours, equal to 86 400 seconds. This also refers to a specific day.
Periodically stopping and starting.
An intense sensation of discomfort or distress that is sharp and feels as though a knife has penetrated an anatomical location.
Lying down.
A discharge of fluid from the nose.
A cough that is not accompanied by expectorated secretions.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
A condition with abnormally high levels of CHOLESTEROL in the blood. It is defined as a cholesterol value exceeding the 95th percentile for the population.

Persistently high systemic arterial BLOOD PRESSURE. Based on multiple readings (BLOOD PRESSURE DETERMINATION), hypertension is currently defined as when SYSTOLIC PRESSURE is consistently greater than 140 mm Hg or when DIASTOLIC PRESSURE is consistently 90 mm Hg or more.
Roll of dried and finely cut TOBACCO leaves wrapped in a cylinder of thin paper used for SMOKING.
Occurring or done each day.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.

A synthetic lipid-lowering agent. Atorvastatin competitively inhibits hepatic hydroxymethyl-glutaryl coenzyme A (HMG-CoA) reductase, the enzyme which catalyzes the conversion of HMG-CoA to mevalonate, a key step in cholesterol synthesis. Atorvastatin also increases the number of LDL receptors on hepatic cell surfaces to enhance uptake and catabolism of LDL and reduces LDL production and the number of LDL particles. This agent lowers plasma cholesterol and lipoprotein levels and modulates immune responses by suppressing MHC II (major histocompatibility complex II) on interferon gamma-stimulated, antigen-presenting cells such as human vascular endothelial cells. (NCI04)
An angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor that is used to treat HYPERTENSION and HEART FAILURE.

A thiazide diuretic often considered the prototypical member of this class. It reduces the reabsorption of electrolytes from the renal tubules. This results in increased excretion of water and electrolytes, including sodium, potassium, chloride, and magnesium. It is used in the treatment of several disorders including edema, hypertension, diabetes insipidus, and hypoparathyroidism.
A clinical manifestation consisting of an unnatural paleness of the skin.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.

The act of breathing with the LUNGS, consisting of INHALATION, or the taking into the lungs of the ambient air, and of EXHALATION, or the expelling of the modified air which contains more CARBON DIOXIDE than the air taken in (Blakiston's Gould Medical Dictionary, 4th ed.). This does not include tissue respiration (= OXYGEN CONSUMPTION) or cell respiration (= CELL RESPIRATION).
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
Expelling modified air from the lungs; breathing out.
Taking ambient air into the lungs; breathing in.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Veins in the neck which drain the brain, face, and neck into the brachiocephalic or subclavian veins.

Swelling due to excessive accumulation of fluid under the skin defined by a persistent indentation when pressure is applied to the swollen area. Causes include systemic conditions (e.g., heart failure, liver failure, or kidney failure) and local conditions affecting the extremities.
A region of the lower extremity immediately surrounding and including the KNEE JOINT.

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
